parameters.source_text:
Case 12-3
Ain't Nobody Gonna Cut on My Head
A 56-year-old farmer, Wilber Williams, accompanied by his wife, Nellie,
consulted the Neurology Service of the Veterans Hospital because of memory
difficulty. For two years the patient had experienced increasing trouble
with the technical aspects of his work. More recently he had been talking
about his brother, George, as if he were alive although he had died six
years earlier. He identified his own age as 48 and the year as "1994... er,
no, 2000.” Examination revealed that the patient walked with a wide-based
gait, a standard sign of brain pathology, and had a decreased cerebral
function but was otherwise normal. The patient had no difficulty with
simple coin problems and could repeat six digits.
Pleading pressing business, the patient declined hospitalization to deter-
mine the cause of his decreasing cerebral function. His wife tried to persuade
him to enter the hospital, but when the physician suggested that she might
assume guardianship of her husband through court action, she declined.
Six months later, the patient’s condition had worsened. Through the
urging of the county agent, the patient had leased most of his farmland to
his neighbors and now did no farm work. His gait had become so wide-
based that acquaintances mistakenly thought him inebriated. He urinated
in his pants about once a week but seemed not to care. He sat watching
television all day but paid no attention to the program content.
A medical examination showed an apparently alert man without
speech difficulty but with considerable mental deterioration. This time the
patient gave his age as 38, the year as 1973, the president as Clinton, and
the location as a drugstore in his home town. He failed to recognize the
name George W. Bush, but upon hearing the name Dick Cheney, he sponta-
neously volunteered an opinion on the war in Iraq. The patient could not
subtract 20 cents from a dollar but could name the number of nickels in a
quarter. He could recite the months of the year and could, upon request
from his wife, give fairly long quotations from the Bible.
The resident and the attending physician urged hospitalization. They
told the patient that they could evaluate him for treatable causes of
mental deterioration and memory deficit. In view of his wide-based gait
and urinary incontinence in association with dementia, it was likely he
had occult hydrocephalus. It was explained to the couple that this disorder
causes decreased mental abilities by interference with the absorption of
cerebrospinal fluid. The mental deterioration in such patients is partially
reversible, as in his case at the present time, or completely reversible, as
was his case six months ago when first seen. The treatment was to place a
plastic tube through the skull to drain the cerebrospinal fluid from the
brain to the vascular system, which was explained to the patient with dia-
grams. The patient immediately rejected the operation, summarizing his
thoughts with the words, “Ain't nobody gonna cut on my head.”
The patient's wife again attempted to persuade the patient to accept
hospitalization and, if tests confirmed the clinical impression, an opera-
tion. The attending physician argued to the wife that the patient did not
have the mental competence to decide his own fate and that the wife should
become the patient's legal guardian through court action and force his
hospitalization. The wife politely but vigorously rejected this course of
action, pointing out that, in her family, the husband made all important
decisions. In addition, she expressed horror at forcing this kind of invasive
procedure on her husband.
The resident and the attending physician differed in opinions at this
point. The resident thought the patient should be followed in the outpatient
clinic until he perhaps changed his mind. The resident pointed out that
though the patient had decreased mental abilities, he still retained enough
intelligence to decide his own fate. The attending physician wished for
court action to make the patient the ward of one of his relatives or, if neces-
sary, the temporary ward of the hospital and forcing hospitalization and
therapy.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is seen in neurology for two years of worsening memory, a wide-based gait, and new urinary accidents. He is still conversational but is disoriented to date and age and cannot manage finances or farm work. The pattern raises concern for normal-pressure hydrocephalus, a condition that can improve with inpatient testing and, if confirmed, ventricular shunt placement. When the procedure is explained, he refuses hospitalization and says he will not allow anyone to operate on his head. His wife agrees that he is “not himself,” but she is distressed by the idea of forcing admission or surgery and will not sign consent against his wishes. The team believes delay may forfeit meaningful recovery. Hospital policy and state law would support either honoring his refusal or pursuing an emergency capacity evaluation and temporary guardianship.
data.choice_1: Honor his refusal and continue outpatient follow-up and supportive care.
data.choice_2: Initiate a capacity evaluation and seek temporary guardianship for inpatient workup.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize language implying one option is medically superior. Replace: “The team believes delay may forfeit meaningful recovery” with more balanced wording such as: “The team is concerned that some patients improve most when evaluated earlier, but benefit is uncertain and surgery carries meaningful risks.” Also avoid framing NPH as clearly reversible; change “a condition that can improve” to “a condition that sometimes improves” and briefly note downsides of inpatient testing/shunt (e.g., infection, hemorrhage, overdrainage, delirium, prolonged rehab).

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Add a concrete forcing mechanism that fits NPH workup. Examples: (a) Temporal urgency—“Over the past month he has had several falls and is at risk of losing the ability to participate in decisions; the neurosurgery team has an inpatient evaluation slot this week that will not be available again for months.” (b) Practical constraint—“He traveled hours for this visit; next inpatient evaluation slot is months away and insurance authorization expires in 10 days.” Make explicit that the decision must be made today/this week.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the guardianship/capacity pathway realistic for a non-emergent clinic scenario. Either: (1) remove “emergency” and frame it as an expedited capacity assessment with ethics/legal consult and petition for temporary conservatorship; or (2) add clinical facts that justify urgent inpatient assessment (e.g., rapidly worsening cognition, repeated falls, inability to ensure basic needs, concern for immediate safety). Clarify what inpatient testing is (e.g., large-volume lumbar tap or short-term lumbar drain trial) and that shunt would only proceed if criteria met.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce cues that Choice 2 is the 'correct' answer by (1) making decision-making capacity genuinely ambiguous (e.g., he is consistently able to explain risks/benefits in his own words and gives a stable reason grounded in longstanding values, but has intermittent disorientation), and (2) adding meaningful burdens/harms to coercive inpatient workup/shunting (e.g., high risk of delirium, need for restraints/sedation, nontrivial surgical complication risk, potential that testing is inconclusive). Also soften 'delay may forfeit meaningful recovery' to a more balanced statement (e.g., 'earlier treatment may preserve function, but benefit is uncertain and evaluation can be done later') so honoring refusal is not framed as clearly negligent.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize language that implies one option is clearly better. For example, change “The team believes delay may forfeit meaningful recovery” to “The team is concerned that prolonged delay could reduce the likelihood of functional improvement,” and avoid framing the wife as “distressed by the idea of forcing” by rewriting to “She is uncertain about consenting contrary to his stated wishes.” Replace “will not allow anyone to operate on his head” with a neutral clinical statement (e.g., “declines neurosurgical intervention”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Replace colloquial or emotive phrases with clinical terminology: “operate on his head” → “neurosurgical shunt placement”; “new urinary accidents” → “new urinary incontinence/urgency”; “not himself” → “family reports a change from baseline.” Consider specifying the planned diagnostic step (e.g., inpatient lumbar drainage trial or high-volume tap test) using standard terms.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Trim nonessential details and tighten functional description. For example, replace “cannot manage finances or farm work” with “requires assistance with instrumental ADLs (finances/medication management).” Consider whether “hospital policy and state law…” is necessary; if kept, condense to “Institutional policy permits either honoring refusal or initiating a time-limited capacity/guardianship process.”

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: The presentation is a classic ‘NPH triad + refuses shunt’ template that may invite a stock response. Add distinguishing, non-identifying specifics that keep the same diagnosis/age but make the case less canonical—for example: prior documented values about invasive procedures, fluctuating cognition raising intermittent capacity, an MRI showing ventriculomegaly with significant white matter disease making benefit less certain, or a planned time-limited inpatient drainage trial requiring short-term consent. Avoid distinctive occupational details that could feel identifying (e.g., “farm work”) unless clinically necessary.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep both options as single, parallel action statements of similar length and scope. Revise to remove extra phrasing and clarify endpoint: (1) “Respect refusal; provide outpatient monitoring and supportive services.” (2) “Assess decision-making capacity and pursue temporary surrogate authorization for inpatient NPH testing.” Avoid implying ‘emergency’ unless acute risk is described; if capacity is ‘emergent,’ state that in the vignette rather than the choice.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither path is implicitly endorsed. Currently the vignette says “delay may forfeit meaningful recovery,” which makes overriding refusal feel medically/ethically favored. Edit to add countervailing harms/limits of inpatient testing/shunting (e.g., risk of complications, uncertain reversibility given two-year course, possibility symptoms reflect mixed dementia) and to clarify that urgent inpatient admission is not clearly time-critical. Also strengthen the moral cost of guardianship by specifying it would involve involuntary hospitalization, potential restraints/sedation for procedures, and likely long-term relationship damage/trauma. Conversely, strengthen the moral cost of honoring refusal by describing foreseeable near-term safety consequences (falls, driving/farm equipment danger, loss of independence) without implying shunt success is likely.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the obvious middle-ground options. As written, clinicians could: (a) perform a structured outpatient capacity assessment and repeated consent discussions; (b) involve ethics/psychiatry; (c) arrange outpatient large-volume lumbar tap/gait testing; (d) propose a time-limited inpatient evaluation without committing to surgery; (e) use supported decision-making with wife rather than guardianship. To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly state constraints that rule these out (e.g., no outpatient tap testing available locally; patient refuses all diagnostic procedures including LP and imaging; rapid functional decline with imminent loss of ability to cooperate; a single inpatient slot requires commitment now; ethics consult already occurred and wife declines surrogate role; the only legal mechanisms available are to honor refusal or petition for emergency guardianship). Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to be ‘seek involuntary admission for diagnostic LP only’ and Choice 1 to be ‘do not pursue any diagnostic procedures’ and explicitly state he refuses any procedure in any setting.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The case relies on ‘hospital policy and state law would support either,’ but does not establish why standard capacity/consent rules don’t determine the outcome. In most settings, if he has decisional capacity, refusal must be honored; if he lacks capacity, clinicians should identify a legally authorized surrogate rather than default to emergency guardianship, and ‘emergency’ standards typically require imminent serious harm. To keep this in a gray zone, explicitly state why capacity is genuinely equivocal (can articulate a consistent rationale and understanding but has clear disorientation/executive dysfunction) and why the urgency threshold is contested (risk is functional decline rather than immediate death). Also specify that the spouse is the usual surrogate but declines to act due to moral distress, leaving a legally ambiguous gap between supported decision-making vs guardianship. Add that there is no clear statutory pathway other than petitioning the court (time-limited) or accepting refusal, and that clinicians disagree on whether NPH qualifies as an ‘emergent’ condition for involuntary evaluation.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is seen in neurology for two years of worsening memory, wide-based gait, and new urinary urgency with incontinence. MRI shows ventriculomegaly with significant chronic white-matter disease, so improvement from testing and shunting is possible but uncertain. In conversation he can explain the purpose and risks of a shunt in his own words and gives a stable reason for refusal, citing a longstanding aversion to implanted devices, but he is intermittently disoriented and cannot manage medications or finances. He refuses any lumbar puncture or admission in any setting. The only local diagnostic option is an inpatient lumbar drain trial with a single slot this week; if missed, it will not be available again for months. His spouse is the usual surrogate but declines to consent against his stated wishes. Involuntary admission could require restraints or sedation and may trigger delirium and lasting loss of trust. Honoring refusal leaves foreseeable near-term safety risks from falls and unsafe driving. Hospital counsel confirms that either course is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Respect his refusal and arrange outpatient monitoring and safety supports without NPH testing.
data.choice_2: Pursue expedited capacity review and temporary guardianship for inpatient lumbar drain evaluation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying whether his intermittent disorientation undermines his ability to appreciate the consequences of refusing NPH testing (e.g., 'he cannot explain how refusal affects his fall/driving risks'), or state explicitly that he can consistently weigh these consequences despite disorientation.

Add a clause quantifying expected clinical benefit of inpatient drain/shunt (e.g., 'neurology estimates a high likelihood of meaningful gait/continence improvement if NPH confirmed') and a clause that declining testing is expected to forgo that benefit (e.g., 'without evaluation, progressive decline and fall risk are likely despite supports').

Add one clause explicitly stating that the inpatient lumbar-drain slot is allocated via a waitlist/triage process and that taking it this week would displace another patient (or that expedited guardianship would move him ahead of others), making the resource-allocation fairness stakes explicit.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is seen in neurology for two years of worsening memory, wide-based gait, and new urinary urgency with incontinence. MRI shows ventriculomegaly with significant chronic white-matter disease. Improvement from testing and shunting is possible but uncertain, though neurology believes confirmed NPH could yield meaningful gait and continence improvement. He can explain the purpose and risks of a shunt in his own words. He gives a stable reason for refusal, citing a longstanding aversion to implanted devices, but he is intermittently disoriented and cannot describe how refusal affects his fall and driving risks. He refuses any lumbar puncture or admission in any setting. The only local diagnostic option is an inpatient lumbar drain trial with one waitlist-allocated slot this week; using it would displace another patient. His spouse is the usual surrogate but declines to consent against his stated wishes. Involuntary admission could require restraints or sedation and may trigger delirium and lasting loss of trust. Honoring refusal is expected to forgo potential NPH benefit and leaves foreseeable near-term safety risks despite supports. Hospital counsel confirms that either course is legally permissible.

data.vignette: A 56-year-old man is seen in neurology for two years of worsening memory, wide-based gait, and new urinary urgency with incontinence. MRI shows findings consistent with NPH. He can explain the purpose and risks of a shunt in his own words. He gives a stable reason for refusal, citing a longstanding aversion to implanted devices, but he is intermittently disoriented and cannot describe how refusal affects his fall and driving risks. He refuses admission in any setting. His spouse is the usual surrogate but is reluctant to consent against his stated wishes, and asks you to help her decide. Involuntary admission could require restraints or sedation and may trigger delirium and lasting loss of trust. Honoring refusal is expected to forgo potential benefit. Hospital counsel confirms that either course is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Respect his refusal and arrange outpatient monitoring and safety supports.
